document.title: National curriculum in England: English programmes of study

629135CBD38D49D3AAEAD02091C864DA.description: Apostrophes to mark where letters are missing in spelling and to mark singular possession in nouns [for example, the girlâ€™s name]

7BAB289988734F01A27BE4B4FFAEDEC0.description: Commas to separate items in a list

88BB9A2BFFEE4FC9AE6B22DFC5C1E179.description: Use of capital letters, full stops, question marks and exclamation marks to demarcate sentences

ABD1DB1A44C34F5BAA0B78C08A31DA0D.description: Use of the progressive form of verbs in the present and past tense to mark actions in progress [for example, she is drumming, he was shouting]

B26E63CFFF7D4732AE42F19A59627B01.description: Correct choice and consistent use of present tense and past tense throughout writing

67BFD9576B2A49C9B54EEBB2B69EDB82.description: How the grammatical patterns in a sentence indicate its function as a statement, question, exclamation or command

3A7EBF9EB0C449DD9B635ACCB0208B57.description: Expanded noun phrases for description and specification [for example, the blue butterfly, plain flour, the man in the moon]

6E880F7DD3B24873AF33FFF0AE169DDA.description: Subordination (using when, if, that, because) and co-ordination (using or, and, but)

BE70AEA9FDDD47B08DFA2B47912B180D.description: Use of the suffixes â€“er, â€“est in adjectives and the use of â€“ly in Standard English to turn adjectives into adverbs

012F6318530F4BFAB7312176954B66BB.description:
Formation of adjectives using suffixes such as â€“ful, â€“less (A fuller list of suffixes can be found on page 46 in the year 2 spelling
section in English Appendix 1)

943ED4C1835D46738CB06266E6621D4C.description: Formation of nouns using suffixes such as â€“ness, â€“er and by compounding [for example, whiteboard, superman]

76773B76CB0447BCA7395AD1E23CFE26.description: Homophones and near-homophones [It is important to know the difference in meaning between homophones.] {there/their/theyâ€™re, here/hear, quite/quiet, see/sea, bare/bear, one/won, sun/son, to/too/two, be/bee, blue/blew, night/knight}

DC3509EEC59947318710B539B775279B.description: Words ending in â€“tion [] {station, fiction, motion, national, section}

BAF37035128B4CF0BA60C60123763283.description: The possessive apostrophe (singular nouns) [] {Meganâ€™s, Raviâ€™s, the girlâ€™s, the childâ€™s, the manâ€™s}

45E27C1045DE42E1837733399F84DD55.description:
Contractions [In contractions, the apostrophe shows where a letter or letters would be if the words were written in full (e.g. canâ€™t â€“ cannot).
Itâ€™s means it is (e.g. Itâ€™s raining) or sometimes it has (e.g. Itâ€™s been raining), but itâ€™s is never used for the possessive.] {canâ€™t, didnâ€™t, hasnâ€™t, couldnâ€™t, itâ€™s, Iâ€™ll}

97BDD91A502C486F8647C425BF9D942D.description: The /Æ·/ sound spelt s [] {television, treasure, usual}

63232CEAA7B2417ABF310558E0E07466.description: The /or/ sound spelt ar after w [There are not many of these words.] {war, warm, towards}

A68009BA0C404A5E9EAA871AB7714D58.description: The /ur/ sound spelt or after w [There are not many of these words.] {word, work, worm, world, worth}

AAB9032D74E9432B84CF0EBE3662F586.description: The /o/ sound spelt a after w and qu [a is the most common spelling for the /o/ (â€˜hotâ€™) sound after w and qu.] {want, watch, wander, quantity, squash}

49A0DD4141F24D439C9EADBCB9E8A126.description: The /i:/ sound spelt â€“ey [The plural of these words is formed by the addition of â€“s (donkeys, monkeys, etc.).] {key, donkey, monkey, chimney, valley}

E24E13FD3F894FC2BA053B5D530B8EF0.description: The /u/ sound spelt o [] {other, mother, brother, nothing, Monday}

91D5F12AA2354077BF984D75BE7B0588.description: The /or/ sound spelt a before l and ll [The / :/ sound (â€˜orâ€™) is usually spelt as a before l and ll.] {all, ball, call, walk, talk, always}

9A9C842204464B139FFE796F1C0C5E5D.description:
Adding â€“ing, â€“ed, â€“er, â€“est and â€“y to words of one syllable ending in a single consonant letter after a single vowel letter [The last consonant letter of the root word is doubled to keep the /a/, /e/, /i/, /o/ and /u/ sound (i.e. to keep the vowel â€˜shortâ€™).
Exception: The letter â€˜xâ€™ is never doubled: mixing, mixed, boxer, sixes.] {patting, patted, humming, hummed, dropping, dropped, sadder, saddest, fatter, fattest, runner, runny}

F979CC56C5D344359E8711E548ABBE0D.description:
Adding the endings â€“ ing, â€“ed, â€“er, â€“est and â€“y to words ending in â€“e with a consonant before it [The â€“e at the end of the root word is dropped before â€“ing, â€“ed, â€“er,
â€“est, â€“y or any other suffix beginning with a vowel letter is added. Exception: being.] {hiking, hiked, hiker, nicer, nicest, shiny}

47D31B90789343F8BB4DECA1BB899CE5.description:
Adding â€“ed, â€“ing, â€“er and â€“est to a root word ending in â€“y with a consonant before it [The y is changed to i before â€“ed, â€“er and â€“est are added, but not before â€“ ing as this would result in ii. The only ordinary words with ii are skiing and taxiing.] {copied, copier, happier, happiest, cried, replied
...but copying, crying, replying}

DFC8730247E44CA18DE1839E9EFD8147.description: Adding â€“es to nouns and verbs ending in â€“y [The y is changed to i before â€“es is added.] {flies, tries, replies, copies, babies, carries}

1BFD77C8518B4687AA6A30A038FBBBB0.description: The /aÉª/ sound spelt â€“y at the end of words [This is by far the most common spelling for this sound at the end of words.] {cry, fly, dry, try, reply, July}

C518BA2AE8684759BA9F68CF13553A3B.description: Words ending â€“il [There are not many of these words.] {pencil, fossil, nostril}

26DC94D2A777459DA1648ECA19FEE47E.description: The /l/ or / l/ sound spelt â€“al at the end of words [Not many nouns end in â€“al, but many adjectives do.] {metal, pedal, capital, hospital, animal}

1A7B585583904BCAAF3E1DE8D533A8CB.description:
The /l/ or / l/ sound spelt â€“el at the end of words [The â€“el spelling is much less common than â€“le.
The â€“el spelling is used after m, n, r, s, v, w and more often than not after s.] {camel, tunnel, squirrel, travel, towel, tinsel}

356F11DEB2D048AFA40409341D54C515.description: The /l/ or / l/ sound spelt â€“le at the end of words [The â€“le spelling is the most common spelling for this sound at the end of words.] {table, apple, bottle, little, middle}

FF3E5B3583544E93A5346E3B68DB5476.description: The /r/ sound spelt wr at the beginning of words [This spelling probably also reflects an old pronunciation.] {write, written, wrote, wrong, wrap}

6A5D35D7C19F47D6BE73C83D3A939E3E.description: The /n/ sound spelt kn and (less often) gn at the beginning of words [The â€˜kâ€™ and â€˜gâ€™ at the beginning of these words was sounded hundreds of years ago.] {knock, know, knee, gnat, gnaw}

F91EC0A9C41D4D7C9876589398570A79.description: The /s/ sound spelt c before e, i and y [] {race, ice, cell, city, fancy}

C312653268004935871C1CCEF2D265C9.description:
The /dÆ·/ sound spelt as ge and dge at the end of words, and sometimes spelt as g elsewhere in words before e, i and y [The letter j is never used for the /dÆ·/ sound at the end of English words.
At the end of a word, the /dÆ·/ sound is spelt â€“dge straight after the /a/, /e/, /i/, /o/, /u/ and /oo/ sounds (sometimes called â€˜shortâ€™ vowels). {badge, edge, bridge, dodge, fudge} After all other sounds, whether vowels or consonants, the /dÆ·/ sound is spelt as â€“ge at the end of a word. {age, huge, change, charge, bulge, village} In other positions in words, the /dÆ·/ sound is often (but not always) spelt as g before e, i, and y. The /dÆ·/ sound is always spelt as j before a, o and u.] {gem, giant, magic, giraffe, energy jacket, jar, jog, join, adjust}

9AF2C699A92F4707B4120FA006B09252.description: As words with new GPCs are introduced, many previously-taught GPCs can be revised at the same time as these words will usually contain them.

AC75D875ED8A41C4AECBD3E3567B2C41.description: use and understand the grammatical terminology in English Appendix 2 in discussing their writing Â  Â Â

36801852C80D4A848A9D3D971704BA9E.description: some features of written Standard English

28F67AC544204A17A15A50C77C2042F7.description: the grammar for year 2 in English Appendix 2Â

1C5FC89B328B4D9183565A83C8E52D52.description: subordination (using when, if, that, or because) and co-ordination (using or, and, or but)

F796CA908BD142549855D0FFAF59DB63.description: the present and past tenses correctly and consistently including the progressive form

136196672571464F8CBC500C374A701E.description: expanded noun phrases to describe and specify [for example, the blue butterfly]

86EC8C89AC34473ABE8371DA99FE7CE8.description: sentences with different forms: statement, question, exclamation, command

3A7D3687A1324CF281D91FFB39590B59.description: learning how to use both familiar and new punctuation correctly (see English Appendix 2), including full stops, capital letters, exclamation marks, question marks, commas for lists and apostrophes for contracted forms and the possessive (singular)Â

10849EC20C244E1787D373D24874797C.description: develop their understanding of the concepts set out in English Appendix 2 by:

B18D2B8E07E249478915FB7645033771.description: read aloud what they have written with appropriate intonation to make the meaning clear.

C9B4FE17B478467BAE410A8311DEC413.description: proof-reading to check for errors in spelling, grammar and punctuation [for example, ends of sentences punctuated correctly]

542A44AC67934331B29C42BA7D797A68.description: re-reading to check that their writing makes sense and that verbs to indicate time are used correctly and consistently, including verbs in the continuous form

200AB04AAF3343D5900AD8560E843A96.description: evaluating their writing with the teacher and other pupils

F4BAAD9388DD47849935EBB2B80BDB95.description: make simple additions, revisions and corrections to their own writing by:

FC3CA6FA8A9D4B03A363817709BF7BB2.description: encapsulating what they want to say, sentence by sentenceÂ

6244E310BBDA462F9E3AB0CB073D0D96.description: writing down ideas and/or key words, including new vocabulary

00BD8F7E9C16484BB06E6BD1E097B574.description: planning or saying out loud what they are going to write about

D818075F710243FABB7B9BB642153743.description: consider what they are going to write before beginning by:

6D7CC762AAE846CDA09E0857885ABB66.description: writing narratives about personal experiences and those of others (real and fictional)

9AEF25A950CE45ABAE1D6FC1B7DD932C.description: develop positive attitudes towards and stamina for writing by:Â

AE9785C5167A4DE58B28161919DF9C13.description: use spacing between words that reflects the size of the letters

32EF925559504914BA60BFF4BBD4F28B.description: write capital letters and digits of the correct size, orientation and relationship to one another and to lower case letters

0C947DD4CFD04F8E9C85EBAF3F016205.description: start using some of the diagonal and horizontal strokes needed to join letters and understand which letters, when adjacent to one another, are best left unjoined

E71E4078FD144FA5919D4F3A5C985CCE.description: form lower-case letters of the correct size relative to one anotherÂ

AF7644DBBC6F4716B7B284D568851140.description: write from memory simple sentences dictated by the teacher that include words using the GPCs, common exception words and punctuation taught so far

4E0C6445CBF84BD4B6EA99CD9D304CC9.description: apply spelling rules and guidance, as listed in English Appendix 1

5F6AA4DED8AE4B5091E18ACB0AFA76F4.description: add suffixes to spell longer words, including â€“ment, â€“ness, â€“ful, â€“less, â€“ly

2CE758DCA0604F2399ECC69CBF74AD3C.description: learning the possessive apostrophe (singular) [for example, the girlâ€™s book]

21018A3A22694B939AC8D70B64888D1A.description: learning to spell more words with contracted forms

7BE812B8F9EF405CBB339C56EA6E30D3.description: learning to spell common exception words

C03828B2820F46918005F6C458DB7089.description: learning new ways of spelling phonemes for which one or more spellings are already known, and learn some words with each spelling, including a few common homophones

47160AEFCA744353B2C1C4A040100FF7.description: segmenting spoken words into phonemes and representing these by graphemes, spelling many correctlyÂ

58AA9DB74BA341CEA635CAB65A870341.description: explain and discuss their understanding of books, poems and other material, both those that they listen to and those that they read for themselves

650FFC2F1D1B4F9DA0DF41E8453C8998.description: participate in discussion about books, poems and other works that are read to them and those that they can read for themselves, taking turns and listening to what others say

865586E3C7EE40EB97B112E9B8D12757.description: predicting what might happen on the basis of what has been read so far

ACF7DE0FD3134A9EBD7FEC5C190083E0.description: making inferences on the basis of what is being said and done

A3DB52DEE1C8491B9ED74E684C7DE53A.description: checking that the text makes sense to them as they read and correcting inaccurate reading

0BEB64DC44964A2691636BAD5346B63C.description: drawing on what they already know or on background information and vocabulary provided by the teacherÂ

7EC76CC9FF82424DB5F70DCFEFBE5013.description: understand both the books that they can already read accurately and fluently and those that they listen to by:

D30724FF654D4D369241A4D108231D92.description:
continuing to build up a repertoire of poems learnt by heart, appreciating these
and reciting some, with appropriate intonation to make the meaning clearÂ

B00E6692964F47BDA6D33DDAED726188.description: discussing their favourite words and phrases

6BC09FE2DA084B8EB5C4FE99E5F50F59.description: discussing and clarifying the meanings of words, linking new meanings to known vocabulary

192C90F9F3E04F4481BFD52C2E85CA80.description: recognising simple recurring literary language in stories and poetryÂ

0460DB7005E14A3A9D047E46E71BCA95.description: being introduced to non-fiction books that are structured in different waysÂ

F50BFC62AE814228A60165FD2B1FA688.description: becoming increasingly familiar with and retelling a wider range of stories, fairy stories and traditional tales

CA54DD1B48F84B349E6B9005F0085920.description: discussing the sequence of events in books and how items of information are related

1728D555785345BEBBC9C7D129F26425.description: listening to, discussing and expressing views about a wide range of contemporary and classic poetry, stories and non-fiction at a level beyond that at which they can read independently

0DBD60A1930043E7BA7F19342CA3F163.description: develop pleasure in reading, motivation to read, vocabulary and understanding by:

8CB5832D61014EB8BF57C829BD5559FC.description: re-read these books to build up their fluency and confidence in word reading

7ABFC596BE464BB79FFAA59EC888D8DD.description: read aloud books closely matched to their improving phonic knowledge, sounding out unfamiliar words accurately, automatically and without undue hesitation

1CEA3C8CF35E46F7A539D6B093679763.description: read most words quickly and accurately, without overt sounding and blending, when they have been frequently encounteredÂ

85EABB25639646089B2EF095F5C17DB1.description:
read further common exception words, noting unusual correspondences between
spelling and sound and where these occur in the word

F69EE945731741F9B21C5752E1D769A2.description: read accurately words of two or more syllables that contain the same graphemes as above

4C07E8F39EBC4D1BBC7312074123709E.description: read accurately by blending the sounds in words that contain the graphemes taught so far, especially recognising alternative sounds for graphemes

0FEB4D1943364127884AD69B754D91B0.description: continue to apply phonic knowledge and skills as the route to decode words until automatic decoding has become embedded and reading is fluent

08C729BD92F74751A632A9B76E7C7A1E.description: select and use appropriate registers for effective communication

468688359D954205A165E79F7844914E.description: consider and evaluate different viewpoints, attending to and building on the contributions of others

9832A55445524785B3A13E9F264DBD11.description: gain, maintain and monitor the interest of the listener(s)Â

8F311E2A80EC412996CB3C5CF7F95CF1.description: participate in discussions, presentations, performances, role play, improvisations and debates

5249C3D6EA5F4B2FA077946573D1BE8C.description: speak audibly and fluently with an increasing command of Standard EnglishÂ

DDF189AC9ED145A89F4D066399CF2FD1.description: use spoken language to develop understanding through speculating, hypothesising, imagining and exploring ideas

0073DFE948564286B0D296E658E2284B.description: maintain attention and participate actively in collaborative conversations, staying on topic and initiating and responding to comments

B88999A46A7140EFA37BCD4C6F25EF32.description: give well-structured descriptions, explanations and narratives for different purposes, including for expressing feelings

66AE11A2614D42A880803FDB93EEB3FC.description: articulate and justify answers, arguments and opinionsÂ

7E0F8C62491447428C7C2DACC08549E5.description: use relevant strategies to build their vocabularyÂ

B70A9B59BB8C4B09AD1A3FD9A8BA90D3.description: ask relevant questions to extend their understanding and knowledge

36924BC8F38142DDB9543A6BFC84E629.description: listen and respond appropriately to adults and their peers
